channel.title: BBC News - Europe

item.title: Sweden charges man over 1988 Iran prison massacre
item.description: Hamid Nouri faces trial over the mass execution of detainees during the Iran-Iraq war.

item.title: Covid: No quarantine for fully jabbed US and EU travellers to England
item.description: The travel industry had been pushing for the rule change so tourists can more easily come to England.

item.title: Roma student: 'My only goal is to finish school'
item.description: How one school in Croatia is working to improve education opportunities for Roma children like Kristina.

item.title: Greece: Forest fire rips through area near Athens
item.description: About 300 firefighters, water-dropping planes and helicopters helped bring the blaze under control.

item.title: Football: Brazil into quarters but Germany exit
item.description: Brazil ease through to the quarter-finals of the men's Olympic football but 2016 silver medallists Germany are eliminated.

item.title: Wales' slate landscape wins World Heritage status
item.description: The north-west slate mining area is said to have "roofed the world" at its height in the 19th Century.

item.title: Brexit: EU pauses legal action against UK over NI Protocol 'breaches'
item.description: The action began in March after the UK made a move to change the implementation of the protocol.

item.title: Dad builds robotic exoskeleton to help son walk
item.description: The French robotics engineer says he was inspired to build the suit after his son asked him to.

item.title: 'Luxury' race will be among most expensive on earth
item.description: A four-day ultramarathon covering 120 miles on the west coast of Scotland will cost Â£15,499 to enter.

item.title: Extreme weather: What causes flash flooding?
item.description: Cities across the world are at risk of extreme rainfall overwhelming their streets

item.title: COP26 climate summit president says progress made, but not enough
item.description: The first in-person climate meeting in 18 months sees some tentative progress, but no breakthroughs.

item.title: Covid passports: How do they work around the world?
item.description: How are countries enforcing vaccine passports and what can people use them for?

item.title: Could Covid vaccine be taken as a pill?
item.description: Researchers are looking at easier ways for people to get the vaccine, including via inhalers and tablets.

item.title: Tips from the Netherlands on how to build a nation of cyclists
item.description: Some tips from the Dutch Cycling Embassy on how to make bikes the easiest and safest way to travel.

item.title: I survived Norway's worst terror attack
item.description: Lisa Husby recalls hiding in fear as far-right extremist Anders Breivik went on a killing spree in 2011.

item.title: Europe floods: 'I have an axe beside my bed'
item.description: Marion Wenzel showed the BBC around her flood-wrecked house in Ahrweiler, Germany.

item.title: First space tourist Dennis Tito: 'I was euphoric'
item.description: Dennis Tito paid $20 million to travel to the International Space Station in 2001.

item.title: Horse racing: Inside the abattoir slaughtering racehorses
item.description: Campaign group Animal Aid set up covert cameras in one of the few slaughterhouses licensed to kill horses.
